As lately he sought the dark grove,</br>Where silence and solitude reign,</br>Thus Corydon, tortur'd with love,</br>Was mournfully heard to complain.
"Thou, Philomel, who with thy strains</br>Can'st calm the rough tempest of care,</br>While the curfew calls homeward the swains,</br>Sweetly warblest a sorrowful air.
"Now hush'd is the wind on the hill,</br>The herds in the plain are at rest,</br>The beasts in the forest are still,</br>But sorrow keeps wakeful my breast.
"Ah!  why, thou sweet songstress of night!</br>Ah, why dost thou plaintively mourn?</br>Thy causes of sorrow are light,</br>Thy pleasures shall quickly return.
"But care, like a cankering worm,</br>Invisibly feeds on my breast;</br>Nought is mine, but in silence to mourn,</br>A stranger for ever to rest.
"For ah!  my Maria has prov'd</br>Inconstant and light as the wind;</br>The nymph whom I tenderly lov'd,</br>Has fled, to my passion unkind.
"Ah!  who could have thought that a form</br>So divine could have harbour'd untruth;</br>But, alas!  she has left me forlorn,</br>She is gone with a treach'rous youth.
"But, why do I mourn thus in vain,</br>Thus pensively sigh to the wind?</br>I cannot but choose to complain,</br>For the nymph that I love is unkind.
"Sweet chorister, ease with thy strains,</br>This burden of woe that I bear;</br>Tell echo to sing o'er the plains,</br>That Corydon dies of despair.
"So haply the story may reach</br>Maria's perfidious ear;</br>And the treach'rous Paridel teach,</br>Both her smiles and professions to fear.
"Ye nymphs, to the swains that ye love,</br>Your vows never heedlessly make;</br>Lest light and inconstant ye prove,</br>And those vows full as heedlessly break.
"Ye shepherds, advised by me,</br>Of deceitfulness ever beware;</br>Tho' lovely and beauteous she be,</br>Yet remember that frail is the fair."
He ceas'd, and beholding the deep</br>Of Avona's impassible wave;</br>He sought by a desperate leap,</br>A relief from his cares in the grave.</br>
